sourceDesc.p: This publication constitutes a remediation of the printed Inns of Court collection. Information on original sources for transcriptions can be accessed via the Document Descriptions.
For a full list of REED collections, editors, executive board members, and staff, please visit http://reed.utoronto.ca/people

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the taxon prefix are pointers to entities in the taxonomy.xml file. For example, taxon:church dereferences to taxonomy.xml#church.
Private URIs using the gloss prefix are pointers to entities in the glossary.xml file. For example, gloss:histrio-1 dereferences to glossary.xml#histrio-1.

projectDesc.p: Records of Early English Drama (REED) is an international scholarly project that is establishing for the first time the context from which the drama of Shakespeare and his contemporaries grew. Founded in 1976, REED has worked since then to locate, transcribe, and edit historical documents containing evidence of drama, secular music, and other communal entertainment and ceremony from the Middle Ages until 1642, when the Puritans closed the London theatres.

body.head: Letter of John Chamberlain to Sir Dudley Carleton 1613-02-25 RLC007

div.head: ff 1-1v(25 February)
div.ab: ...our reuells and triumphes within doores gaue great contentment beeing both daintie and curious in deuise and sumptuous in shew. Specially the ynnes of court whose two maskes stoode them in better then 4000 li. | besides the gallantrie and expence of priuate gentlemen, that were but ante-ambulones, and went only to accompanie them. and our Grayes ynne men and the ynner Templers were nothing discouraged for all the first dodge, but on Saterday last20 February 1612/13 performed theyre parts exceeding well, and with great applause and approbation both from the king and all the companie. the next night21 February 1612/13 the the King inuited the maskers with theyre assistants to the number of forty to a solemne supper in the new mariage roome where they were well treated and much graced with kissing his maiestes hands, and euery one hauyng a particular accoglienzaThis is Italian for hospitality:SOURCE from him the king husbanded the matter so well that this feast was not his owne cost, but he and his companie went yt vpon a ... of running at the ring of the Prince and his nine followers, who payed thirty pound a man: The King Queen Prince Palatin and Lady Elizabeth sat at a table by themselues: and the great Lords and Ladies with the maskers (aboue fowrescore in all) sat at another long table, so that there was no roome for them that made the feast but they were faine to be lookers on. which the young Lady Rich tooke no great pleasure in to see her husband (who was one that payed not so much as a rincke for his monieclosing parenthesis omitted. The ambassadors that were at this wedding and shewes were the French Venetian Count Henry and Caron for the States. the Spaniard was, or wold be sicke, and the archdukes ambassador beeing inuited for the second day made a sullen excuse: and those that were present were not altogether so pleased, but that I heare euery one had some puntilo of disgust....

body.head: Letter of John Chamberlain to Sir Dudley Carleton 1613-12-23 RLC007

div.head: ff 1-1v(23 December)
div.ab: ...Sir Francis Bacon prepares a maskeThe Masque of Flowers, 6 January 1613/14 to honor this mariageie, that of Robert Ker, earl of Somerset, and Lady Frances Howard on 26 December 1613 which will stand him in aboue 2000 li., and though he haue ben offered some helpe by the house, ^and specially by master Sollicitor Sir Henry Yeluerton, who wold haue sent him 500 li., yet he wold not accept yt, but offers them the whole charge with the honor: mary his obligations are such as well to his Maiestie as to the great Lord, and to the whole house of Howards as he can admit no partners. in the mean time his house and land at Goramberie (by St Albons) is gon some say to the earle of Somerset others to the earle of Suffolk, but his bountie is no whit abated, for he feasts the whole vniuersitie of Cambrige. this christmas, and hath sent warrants to his friends and acquaintaunce far and neere to furnish him with venison to bestow on the colleges. he caries a great port as well in his traine as in his apparell and other wayes, and liue sat a great charge, and yet he pretends he will take no fees nor entermeddle in mercenarie causes, but wholy applie himself to the kinges affaires....

body.head: Letter of John Chamberlain to Sir Dudley Carleton 1614-01-05 RLC007

div.head: ff 1v-2(5 January)
div.ab: ...The Lord mayorSir Thomas Middleton was sent to by the King to entertain this new maried couple with theyre frends and followers, but he making an excuse that his house was too litle to receue them, yt was not accepted, but word sent backe that he might commaund the biggest hall in the towne: wherupon calling a counsaile yt was resolved to do yt at the charge of the citie in the marchanttaylers hall vpon fowre dayes warning, and thether they went yesternight about sixe a clocke, thorough cheapside all by torch-light, accompanied by the father and mother of the bride, and all the Lords and Ladies about the court. the men were well mounted and richly arrayed making a goodly shew, the women all in coaches. I do not heare yet how all things passed there, for I haue not ben abrode, only I vnderstand that after supper they had a play and a maske and after that a banket. the bride had a goodly new rich coach, which could not be furnished with fowre horses to theyre mind, so that Sir Rafe winwod was moued t on sonday night2 January 1613/14 to lend his, (those that you may remember he had here fowre or fiue yeares ago, and are as fayre or fayrer then euer they were:) he made aunswer thatfri yt was not for such a Lady to vse any thing borrowed and therfore the next morning presented them to the great Lord, who made some difficultie at first to receue them of guift, but only as lent for this solemnitie of going through the citie, but in the end tooke them in very goode part. Master atturneyesie, Sir Francis Bacon’s maske is for to morrow, and for a conclusion of christmas and these shewes together, for the King sayes he wilbe gon toward Roiston vpon friday7 January 1613/14. before the holy-dayes the french and venetian ambassadorsSamuel Spifame, Seigneur des Bisseaux, and Antonio Foscarini,Don Diego di Sarmiento de Acuna were inuited to this maske, with excuse that they could not be so well at the first vpon the marriage night, for auoyding competition of place and precedence with the Spanish ambassador who had neuer seen any of our shewes before: but the best maske was reserved for them. the french seemed to take yt well enough: but the venetian stormed he shold be excluded and the archdukes admitted, who he presumed wold not | once make offer to take place where he was…

body.head: Letter of John Chamberlain to Sir Dudley Carleton 1616-10-12 RLC007

div.head: f 1(12 October)
div.ab: ...the Princescreation is apointed to be the fowrth of the next moneth with much solemnitie of tilting barriers, and a maske forby;MSdamaged the ynnes of cowrt....
